list_page_teaser: David Lynch's characters can be quite quirky.  Is their quirkiness evident in their spiritual portraits?  Click to find out!
description_html:
This gallery contains spiritual portraits from the fictional town of Twin Peaks.

This gallery is a work in progress. To see the personalities of additional characters from the show, check back later.
story_html:
I will be adding portraits to this gallery very soon — hopefully within a week or two!

To learn when I post new images, follow this site on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

image_list.title: Laura Palmer
image_list.subtitle_html: Homecoming Queen at Twin Peaks High School
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Laura Palmer's spiritual portrait shows she is intuitive and emotional.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in Laura Palmer's spiritual portrait represents her dominant personality trait, her preference for seeing the world in terms of ideas more than facts.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  She exhibits this trait in the way her conversations with others, especially her close friends and lovers, often take on a dreamy, surrealistic quality.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in Laura Palmer's spiritual portrait represents her auxiliary personality trait, her passion and warmth.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  She exhibits this trait in the way she is friendly and popular with her friends, schoolmates, and other acquaintances.
image_list.story_intro_html:
As the beautiful Homecoming Queen of Twin Peaks High School, Laura Palmer is popular and has every reason to be happy. She has secrets, though — including multiple boyfriends and a drug habit.

Life Is but a Dream

The television series starts with Laura's death, but she is the main character in the movie, a prequel titled Twin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me. The iconic Sheryl Lee is excellent in the role, portraying Laura as someone who, in the days before her murder, is becoming increasingly out of touch with reality.

The Blue in her portrait — representing her preference for ideas over facts — shows this tendency. And the following excerpt from a casual conversation with her best friend Donna Hayward one lazy afternoon shows how she doesn't hesitate to let go of reality and allow her mind to drift to fantasy:

Donna: Do you think that if you were falling in space, that you would slow down after a while, or go faster and faster?
Laura: Faster and faster. And for a long time, you wouldn't feel anything. And then you'd burst into fire. Forever. And the angels wouldn't help you, because they've all gone away.
 —  Twin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me, 1992.

And in Laura's case, her imagination drifts into darker and darker places.

Overriding Feeling of Fatalism

Because the film came out a year after the series ended, it is difficult to imagine a viewer who did not know the ultimate outcome beforehand. As the movie progresses, the overriding sense of fatalism becomes progressively more and more palpable.

One of the best of these premonitions occurs when the inimitable Log Lady, played by Catherine Coulson, approaches Laura outside the Bang Bang! bar:

[Puts her hand on Laura's forehead, as if to feel her temperature.] When this kind of fire starts, it is very hard to put out. The tender boughs of innocence burn first. And the wind rises, and then, all goodness is in jeopardy. [Allows her hand to drift downward to Laura's cheek, then down further to briefly hold her hand before releasing it and walking away.]
 — The Log Lady in Twin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me, 1992.

This spiritual portrait is based on the movie Twin Peaks: Fire, Walk With Me.
